ironic/common/pxe_utils.py.message: world writable would catch us in some hot water as we would be functionally disregarding umask all the time... but a file_permission might make sense, or a default permission maybe?

Thats what I thought, but both fileutils.ensure_tree and os.makedirs also default to 0o777. So I tried that locally:

  >>> import os
  >>> os.makedirs('bar', mode=0o777)
  >>> 
  [root@sbaker-t590 foo]# ls -l
  total 8
  drwxr-xr-x. 2 root root 4096 Sep 16 10:44 bar
  drwxr-xr-x. 2 root root 4096 Sep 16 10:36 foo
  [root@sbaker-t590 foo]# umask
  0022

Also the docs[1] say of the mode argument: "Where it is used, the current umask value is first masked out."

So I think 0o777 is appropriate.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.mkdir

nit s/mode/mode=mode/

might be useful to add a comment that the current umask value is first masked out of 'mode'.

OH. Any idea which platforms this might apply to, wrt 'mode'? "On some platforms, they are ignored and you should call chmod() explicitly to set them". (from https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.html#os.mkdir).

> nit s/mode/mode=mode/
Done

> might be useful to add a comment that the current umask value is first masked out of 'mode'.
Agreed, I've done it in the pxe conf help. Its a non-obvious python quirk

> OH. Any idea which platforms this might apply to, wrt 'mode'?
It is quite ambiguous, but I read the "On some platforms " sentence as referring to "bits other than the last 9" in the sentence before. Either way I would hazard that "some platforms" refers to platforms we don't care about ;)
I'll change this to 0o755 for consistency

I thought I'd look to see where else dir_permission is being used. This has 0o755; the other uses 0o777. I think, if possible, we should be consistent. (And my other thought is to change the config itself to default to one of these values but not sure what others think of that.)

whitebox_tempest_plugin/api/compute/test.message: misplaced line or do u even need this?
Thanks yea this is definitely not needed, I think I fat fingered my mouse M3 paste button when I copied the line to delete it in an earlier iteration.
You don't need, just setting min_microversion and/or max_microversion on the class is enough.
A docstring would be nice to explain the params.

In the follow up patch set I actually changed this approach from having a base method.  The reason for the change (and why it was failing earlier) was leaving DifferentHostFilter while forcing min_microversion to 2.74 was causing a migration error due to the removal of force from live migration from in microversion 2.68.  I could keep common base test methods and just create conditional logic that does the extra scheduling based on the min_microversion (i.e. DifferentHostFilter for 2.68 and less or host parameter for 2.74 and higher) but for I removed the methods and just opted to put the logic down in the the child classes.
I thought we got rid of this? Tempest magically does this for you, just set min_ and/or max_microversion on the class.

This has changed the patch's... "feel".

Previously, a refactor made sense because all the same code was reused in two different test classes. Now that this is a separate class, it's repeating the same mistakes I made when writing the NUMA live migration tests - introspecting, and not consuming declarative config options. If we just kept that code in one place, we could merge things that use it, because we'd still have just 1 place where to refactor. Now that you're adding more similar code, it's adding  tech debt.

So here's what I think we should do: merge the colocation test, with its new NUMA config options, as a standalone change on top of master. Once that's done, or on top of that, rewrite the legacy NUMA LM test to consume them, and be less "smart" about how it does things. That will get rid of the need for the DifferentHostFilter. Then, in a third patch, we should be able to reuse the legacy NUMA LM logic with cpu_dedicated_set.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I like the idea of having pagination support in zuul-web. I've made a similar change https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/746328/3/zuul/driver/sql/sqlconnection.py a long time ago (with a follow up that includes the pagination in the frontend). However, the drawback was the performance of the SQL query which resulted in much longer query durations (at least in our setup). I'm not sure how to tackle this but I think this will be the main blocker for a pagination.

If I understand correctly, this change computes the total build count for a given query. Perhaps we could do the pagination without knowing the total, e.g. the widget could assume there is always more result, until the API returns an empty list. That has the extra benefit of not breaking the API.

After discussing this with Tristan, I think it's wiser to drop the API break. We should add instead a possibility to write search queries with conditions on the builds/buildsets' primary key indices. Thus "SELECT ... LIMIT 50 OFFSET 100" would become "SELECT ... WHERE id > XXX LIMIT 50", which would increase performance as it uses an optimized index.

We will lose informations like page count and total results, and searching backwards becomes a little harder, but I think we can live with that.

Users probably do not need to know the exact number of results that a search query would return. But if we want to be precise, we can add the following:

- add "api/tenant/{tenant}/[builds|buildsets]/count" endpoints, used to query the amount of results a search query would return.
- add a cache in the sqlreporter to cache the SQL count queries' results, so as to lower the load on the database.

-1: I couldn't find anything about when services need to implement domain support.  My understanding is that if cinder makes the "List volumes" request be governed by a non-system-scoped rule, when enforce_scope=True by default, the system-administrator will no longer be able to list all the volumes known to cinder (which is appropriate given how we are defining system-admin in this here spec).  But a project-admin will only be able to list the volumes in a project on which they have an 'admin' role (and do it one at a time, i.e., separate requests with a different token for each project.  In the pop-up meetings we discussed at one point that a domain-scoped token could be used to list all the volumes of all the projects in the domain on which you have an appropriate role (I guess 'admin'?), which would work in cinder by changing the meaning of the '?all_tenants=true' query parameter on the list volumes request to mean "all the projects in your domain".

Anyway, this affects this part of the Z-release Timeline:

  #. Any service that completed `Phase 1`_ in Yoga can set ``enforce_scope=True``
     by default

If my analysis above is correct, this will break "List volumes" across projects for cinder (and same thing for similar resources for other services).  I think adding domain support to Phase 1 may be scope creep, so maybe we need a Phase 1.5, and then the turn-on in Z is contingent on satisfying through Phase 1.5.

Otherwise, this document captures all the discussions I've been part of during the Yoga PTG and followup TC and policy pop-up meetings, and additionally is nicely written.  Thanks, Lance!

goals/proposed/consistent-and-secure-rba.message:
This doesn't read very well.

s/system-scoped tokens/operators/

"Relax" sounds like the assumption might still be valid. Aren't we dropping the assumption that system-scoped tokens can *automatically* (emphasis added) access any API? As the next paragraph explains, system admins can give themselves project level access, but the point is they need to take steps (it isn't automatic).

To be clear, the next paragraph about "giving themselves access" means giving themselves a role on that project, not allowing system-scoped tokens to access project resources. If they tried to do the  latter, they would run into all the same trouble as today, which is why we're correcting this course. Meaning, if they override the policy to allow system tokens to start/stop instances, such requests will fail with a 500. By setting scope_types=[project] on our rules, we remove their ability to grant system-scoped users such access, since that's defined on the rule and not in the check string.
Done

I agree with Alan about the wording.  We are not relaxing an assumption here, we are imposing a constraint that system-scoped personas *cannot* act on project-level resources.  The points in the "To clarify" paragraph below explain that this constraint is not unduly burdensome, but I think we need to be clear that we are tightening things up, not relaxing them.
+1, let's make it clear about what new direction we are going not the one we did in past and changing it.

Nope, I'm not saying you're wrong I just wanted to make sure we agreed on what "giving themselves access" meant. Sounds like we do. I'm all for pedantry over words and phrases like this, and I think we've demonstrated that it's very important to be precise in these matters :)

I fully agree. I just interpreted "relax the assumption" to mean the assumption might still be valid that system admins "should *automatically* be able to access any OpenStack API." It won't be automatic; they need to grant themselves access.

Maybe I'm being pedantic, and we can disregard my comment if others are OK with the current wording.

Going back to Sean's point about delegating role assignment to the end-user within a project. We've approached that use case from the domain level.

For example, domain users (e.g., administrator) are able to add and remove users to projects within their domain.

We thought about opening this up to other users at the project level for hierarchical projects (e.g., if project A is a parent of project B, then a project-admin of project A and add and remove users on project B). But, we decided to punt on that functionality until we get a little further down the road. I think we can get a lot of mileage out of the domain personas and fully baking the role assignment work into hierarchical projects felt like we were over-engineering the solution when we weren't sure if we really needed it yet.

Thinking about this more in the last few days, and discussing with a few people...I feel like this probably brings more benefit than phase 2. Is there any reason we couldn't swap this position with phase 2 so we get the service role earlier?

In trying to weigh what operators get for all of this investment, I definitely think that service users are already too powerful, and the system scope stuff in phase 2 likely provides very small benefit to many people. If we're arranging these in order of "most bang for the buck" and "what are users most interested in," wouldn't we put the service role formalization and tightening the policy for them ahead of the system scope stuff?

Maybe I'm missing some dependency that makes the ordering have to be like this, but if not...maybe it'd be better to flip these?

Well, the way I look at it is: Phase 1 is about two things: standardizing roles and making sure project_foo doesn't automatically have the same amount of power as member. The service role thing is similar: standardizing another role and massively reducing the scope of stuff it can do in our default policy (i.e. not having to get admin or member to machines). That leaves system scope to come after the roles are sorted, and really is a totally different thing, which is categorizing some APIs as "system-only and thus no need for project assignments for access control." Put that way, we're not only getting the most bang stuff earlier, but we're also grouping similar activities into adjacent windows (IMO at least).

Know what I mean?

One advantage to keeping things grouped together would be maintaining the momentum on a single idea (system-scope), but that's an organizational opinion and I can't justify it in any meaningful way compared to the benefits we get applying the principle of least privilege to service accounts (which would be a huge win).

Yeah - I think so.

Phase 1 is still going include moving some of the functionality out of the project-admin persona and into the system-admin persona, right?

Yep - Ok. I think that makes sense. Flipping phase 2 and phase 3 allows us to roll out the service role bit sooner, which would be another huge win.

That section is specifically calling out that OpenStack APIs that provide some way for an administrator to list all resources across tenants should continue to work as it does today (even though it is wrong).

For example, we're going to continue allowing someone with the 'admin' role on a project to list all instances in the entire deployment, even though it violates the tenancy of the project that token is scoped to.

Eventually, this behavior should be updated so that ?all_tenants=True should be called with a domain-scoped token and it will return all the resources for all projects within that domain.

I think we've agreed that using domain tokens in this way makes sense organizationally and from a security perspective, but we've already got a full plate for the next few releases. When we get the point where services can start implementing domain user support, we should refactor that work then and not allow project-admins to view all instance/volumes in the entire deployment.

I guess I'm not sure how this really changes things for that scenario. The system user can see the raw host information, sure, and could have (if we made it possible with lots of changees) booted  an instance on behalf of some user on that host. However, the project-scoped slightly-more-super user (i.e. manager) still has the same position here as it did before, needing to see only a fraction of the hosts, with sensitive information (i.e. hostnames) properly sanitized, both incoming and outgoing.

Yeah, and if it requires physical hardware/topology knowledge, it makes sense for that to be an admin role, not project manager. This is probably a good example of a project-scoped resource that requires more-than-project-scoped knowledge, and demonstrates the need for the admin/manager split.

Before, I looked at questions like this as "who should be able to do this?"

Certainly, operators should be allowed to create provider networks, but  not necessarily using a system-scoped token. Instead, I think the important part is that we're acknowledging the owner of the resource and not mixing the ownership with scope (e.g., if a resource is truly project-scoped, like networks, then you must use a project-scoped token to interact with them.)

Otherwise, the thing we've discovered is that mixing the ability for system users to interact with project or domain resources just allows operators to continue using their big hammers.

Now, I think I'm trying to look at these questions from the perspective of what owns the resource (e.g., project, domain, or system) since operators can switch profiles when needed and that leads to a cleaner, more secure design.

If doing anything useful with a provider network requires knowledge of the underlying network topology in the lab, then I'd say it should be limited to project-admin personas so long as the provider network is always owned by a project.

If a provider network is a project-specific resource, and if changes to it would affect other projects in the deployment, then I'd say that project-admins are the right persona to invoke that action. The manager role is intended for people with some extra privileges on top of member. So, project-managers might be able to forcibly reboot an instance for example.

If provider networks are completely isolated to a single project, then maybe we consider delegating it to project-managers.

That is not how it works AFAIK. An admin starting with a domain-scoped token has just that: a domain-scoped token that carries roles assigned on that domain. That token is as useless for taking action on a project resource as a system-scoped token in that it has no project affiliation. IF the role assignment on the domain is marked as inherited on projects within, then that user would also be able to grab a project-scoped token with those inherited roles to take action on a project resource, and the act of doing so would be an auditable event.

If the user has the domain role, but it is not inherited to the projects, then they could do things like the project-wide list, but not grab a token and take action on those resources. Similarly, a user may have the admin role on a project, giving them that power for those resources, but without the ability to list across all projects, or the implication that they have the same power on sibling projects.

I disagree with the assertion that there must be a single god user that can do anything without any auditing. Even modern operating system design specifies that nobody logs in interactively as root and does everything through sudo for the purposes of auditing.

I don't think domains need to be considered ephemeral, or that we need to worry about domains being created at a high rate. Further, I expect that domain creation involves a fair bit of automation which can add roles to admin users upon creation.

I do think it would be nice if we could add roles on the root to make this automatic, but that's a keystone design decision which I expect will require some discussion and obviously a change in how things are currently exposed. Currently there's no actual isolation between domains and an admin anywhere is admin everywhere, so some additional work in complex environments that allows us some incremental progress towards decomposing that seems totally reasonable to me.

I understand the frustration caused by the ambiguity of using the term "admin" for a decade and how it's caused a lot of confusion. I think what we have here is being more specific about what we think a project-admin is and what they can do.

I agree that re-using project-admin, even if it does require resetting our expectations and thoroughly documenting them, is less work than omitting it altogether in favor of something else. To me, that seems like an easier path forward than introducing another alias and then trying to educate users about that.

Where we landed was that removing admin terminology, while perhaps appropriate, would be a ton of work. The conversation ended with a goal of creating a "manager" role to house the "slightly elevated permissions" person that we previously called "project admin" and reserve admin for actual operator-y things.

I think the benefit there is that currently "admin" means "operator-level privilege" and a user able to do very scary things. The previous approach of redefining "project admin" as "actually some end-user person" is more of a change and harder to communicate properly to people used to having admin mean "god". Thus the manager role being that new thing and continuing to use "admin" for operator-level power (even if restricted to one project) maps today and tomorrow much more closely.

the only way the policy framwork could model this woudl be vai a domain member or domain admin token assuming bot project shared a domian.

so i dont think any of the personas in this current goal doc can correctly model the permission needed for
neutron rbac api. since it was created it has been expanded to cover shareign of many other resouce between projects so this is a probelm that will get worse over time. https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-rbac.html

Ok, going back to the physical provider network example. This sounds exactly like images in glance, where they have to be associated to some project even though they are used across multiple projects.

I'd still stay that because they require a project on the resource, we should keep this operation isolated to project-admins. So, if you want to create a physical provider network and make it public, you need to do that within a specific project. Maybe something like:

  $ openstack project create physical_networks
  $ export OS_PROJECT_NAME=physical_networks
  $ openstack network create external_net


I'm struggling to understand why the RBAC API in neutron couldn't be exposed to project-admins?

well external networks are normally owned by the admin project because then have to be owned by some project but they are kind of system resocues in a way since they host the subnet used for floating ips.

the first point i was trying to make is that the  POST /network endpoint will need to have multiple policies for the same url


network that are created with phyical_network set or the segmentation_id would need to be project_admin and request that do not contain does need to be project_member.

but in both cases the url will be the same its only the body that will be different.
shared (a globally shared network) and external network likely shoudl require project admin to create too.


the second point i was trying to make is that there seam to be a gap with how to model neutorn rbac api.

the have an actull rbac rest api that allows resouces owned by one porject to be shared with other projects.


currently i dont think project admin would have sufficent right to use that rbac api since the project admin token only grants the admin role on one of the two project involed. The token is either valid for the 
project that owns the resouce to be shared or the proejct that it is being shared with but not both.

without use a domain amin token to do the shareding i dont see how any of the personas in this current spec could be sued for that api endpoint.

If I understand correctly, if physical networks require knowledge of how the lab is setup, then I think that's even more of a reason to put that operation into the project-admin bucket. Unless there are networks in neutron that can't be owned by a project?

goals/selected/yoga/consistent-and-secur.message:
I'm going to be a jerk here, and I'm sorry.

But a "stretch" goal on an effort which we've not made anywhere near the level of progress many of us in the community have desired, plus where projects are *already* at varying levels including *done* on the core original goal, creates a situation which is exactly what we do not want, which is cross-project inconsistency.

If we're going to do this, it either needs to be a mandatory "this is expected" item, or it needs to be removed from the cycle goal and made an explicit goal for the next cycle. There is no real in-between where this is a "maybe if we have time and capacity and all that" maybe goal.

From Yoga cycle onwards, we are going to start writing the Techncial Guidlines in project-team-guides (Item#1 in https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tc-yoga-tracker), I think RBAC is good candidate for that along with unified limit. These stretch goal things can be evolved in as guides and then once they are all good then we can start adding as goal or so.

One more thing to note is that, as we are going to decouple the goals from release cycle, we can keep RBAC as one of the active goal for many milestone(cycle) and Yoga as first milestone to get things in as agreed in RBAC goals. And adding these strech goals things as next milestone/cycle.

That's fair.

The main reason why we wanted to include this is because we want to write down the overall direction we're headed. Especially when we're talking about things that takes cycles, if not years to complete.

I'd stated in previous iterations of this goal that I wasn't sure if that future direction should live in this goal. But, we don't really have a good parking lot for those ideas to live. Do you have an alternative in mind for capturing that context without bloating the goal?

A potential solution would be to create multiple community goals. Each would be written to target exactly what needs to happen in each release and  create a dependency between them (e.g., this goal needs to get done before we tackle anything in the Z release.)

That would work today, but as soon as something slips or a deadline is missed, we will need to update the goals (maybe that's the right answer...)

I get the reason for having clear and explicit goals, but I also want to preserve the holistic vision we've worked on, and where we're going.

I'm open to suggestions here.

honestly im not sure we should proceed with this as a goal at all without the strach goal as part of the main goal.

i dont think we really are ready to proceed with the cross project goal until we fiture out the corss service interaction among other things or have the project scoped higher privelage then user role.


i need to re read the current verion of hte draft goal as ill admin i have not kept track of all the discussion but form what we discussed at the ptg and my previous skim over this doc i am not convcied we shoudl move forward with this until we actully get more alingment.
yeah, it is merged now (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/governance/+/816387) and we can see how things are divided into different miletsone.
decouple the goals from release cycle i think would help yes.
Think you mean 'real-world' here?
Yes. I've clearly been working on too much read-only policy.
as easy as possible for operators
Done
role:admin  as we discussed in today call so that we keep it same as it is today and late in future when we will enable scope by default or so then we can introduce the system_reader things.
Done

and important thing to note here is we do not have scope embedded in check_str now and this way enfore_scope=False will keep working for operators. may be good to mention that as a separate line or so.
Done

as discussed in today call, we are going to keep system admin for all of these system level operation even GET as first step (until we switch the new RBAC by default). May be this doing system member/reader can be as next step in 'Future goal(s)' ?
Done
you mean "check string that operate with enfore_scope=false" right? which means remove the scope-bits from check_str like 'system:all' etc.
I think so? Did we decide if we were going to break policies that operate with different scoped into multiple rules?

We agreed to keep system admin to keep GET system level APIs not system reader so that if enforce_scope is false then project reader/member would not be able to list system level info (GET hypervisors or so). Only admin (system admin if scope is enabled and project admin if scope is disable) can get system level info which is not change from what it is currently. And later in future when we ake enforce_scope=true or hardcoded-true then we can introduce the system reader here. It will be like:

check_str: role:admin
scope_type: [system]
nit: due to the?
Done

This section is new and was one of the bigger outcomes in the last meeting with the TC.

We need to smooth this part out - but the following section lays out the basic steps.
Glance needs to find how compatible openstackclient is with recently added new features.

I think we're not expecting "each service" to be configured for new defaults and scope in Yoga, right? We're expecting those to be the case for keystone, and in nova in Z. *After* Z, those are expected to be set for the other projects.

My understanding was:
* Enabling the new defaults and scope by default in
** Keystone in Yoga
** Nova in Z
** Other projects in after Z

But Nova or other projects can start implementing the new defaults, scope in their policy in Yoga itself but keep them disable by default and mention it as experimental in release notes.

I know it was challenged in the last round, but I think that it's important to keep the "where we're going" part in here as you have it. This is a long road, it's complicated, and I think knowing/remembering where the end is will help.

Question:
So manager role will be tied with project scope only, right?
Or in future there will be system-manager as well?

In theory - it could be applicable to any scope.

Right now, the clear examples we see for manager is within the project-scope, but that's not to say there aren't good use-cases for it within system-scope.

I think keeping the implementation flexible so that we can apply it to any scope is a good idea and leaves doors open to other options in the future.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: This really should have a reno but it's such a small change and quite breaking so I prefer to just merge it.

The removal of this is covered by this release note:

```
(venv) [vagrant@operator notes]$ git blame remove-monasca-log-transformer-bdcb3ef1cdbc1611.yaml
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000  1) ---
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000  2) upgrade:
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000  3)   - |
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000  4)     Monasca Log Transformer has been merged with Monasca Log Persister to
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000  5)     improve performance and reduce resource consumption. Any custom Monasca
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000  6)     Log Transformer configuration should be either merged into Monasca Log
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000  7)     Persister configuration, or moved outside of the Monasca pipeline, for
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000  8)     example, to Fluentd. Any custom Monasca Log Metrics config will also
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000  9)     need to be updated to read from the raw logs pipeline, rather than the
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 10)     transformed logs pipeline. The transformed logs pipeline will be
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 11)     removed from Kafka automatically, as will any log transformer containers.
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 12)     There will be a short interruption to logging services whilst the
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 13)     pipeline is updated. During this time it's likely that a small window
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 14)     of logs will be lost from the transformed logs Kafka queue. If this
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 15)     is a problem, the Monasca API should be stopped on all nodes prior to
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 16)     upgrading Monasca. This will allow the transformed logs topic to drain
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 17)     into Elasticsearch before the pipeline is reconfigured. Services such
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 18)     as Fluentd, which post logs to the Monasca API, should buffer logs
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 19)     whilst this happens up to the maximum configured buffer. Note that
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 20)     there may be other services forwarding logs, and these will need to be
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 21)     inspected independently. The Log Transformer volumes will remain on
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 22)     the monitoring nodes and can be manually removed as described in the
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 23)     `documentation
0743a9bf4b (Doug Szumski 2021-01-07 17:14:15 +0000 24)     <https://docs.openstack.org/kolla-ansible/latest/reference/logging-and-monitoring/monasca-guide.html#cleanup>`__.

```

build-tools/stx/debrepack.py.message:
run_shell_cmd has error handling but will also raise an exception under certain circumstances, do we want to continue the rest of this function or should we put this in a try/except block and deal with the exception?

As usual I will ask why python native copyfile or os.path.copy aren't used here? Especially now that we seem to have some of shell commands and other python native (see package() at the end of this file, "shutil.copy(source, self.output)" is used). Let's be consistent with this.
Understood. Thanks for replacing the python native copy for consistency.

run_shell_cmd() is used to wrap subprocess.Popen in a try/except block to avoid wrapping subprocess.Popen everywhere. I think the try/except block in run_shell_cmd() can handle all exceptions, otherwise the run_shell_cmd() is senseless. The raise in the exception terminates the whole process once a shell command fails, because it may cause unexpected result.

I will replace the shutil.copy with cp. Thank you for porting it out. I prefer to use a shell commands other than python modules. a/f1

The get_topdir() is to check if a tar ball has top directory, covering not top directory, or one and only file, etc. tar_cmd() gets the corresponding tar commandline.

swift/obj/ssync_receiver.py.message: Does this have any rolling upgrade implications? Or was the client already doing sane things?

An old sender will continue to log an error, but with the :WARN: message:

  test-ssync-sender ERROR: 127.0.0.1:52162/dev/9 Unexpected response: ":WARN: 0 '0.9990620613098145 seconds: /var/folders/n4/nf8krx110f39llj82fbw_xjm0000gp/T/tmp4o2g1z66/tmp_test_ssync_receiver/dev/.lock'"

As for the disconnect:

If the sender has sent all its missing check bytes and is waiting for a receiver response, it will get the timeout message and close its connection. The change avoids a BrokenPipe exception on the receiver.

If the sender has stalled while sending missing_check bytes, it will eventually timeout (same as before) . Maybe bytes get drained in receiver's wsgi, but these are just missing check bytes so relatively few, and the change avoids the BrokenPipe traceback.

The forceful disconnect seems more valuable when the protocol has reached updates phase and the sender is sending object data.
the assumption is the sender will close the connection when it reads back the warning (after sending all the missing check or blocking and timing out)

Maybe the 'SsyncWarning' is a misnomer for an Exception, but I'm not sure I think of it as an anti-pattern any more than StopIteration or DiskFileExpired.

Apologies for the late comment on this review ... 

Panko is retired in current/master versions of openstack ... but for Ussuri (WRO) panko was still supported.  If we remove panko for WRO@Ussuri, is the replacement available in Ussuri ?


( ... I know this was part of re-aligning to current version of 'openstack helm' project, in order to pick up current versions of helm charts ... but worried now that in doing that the helm charts that we are using are now aligned to more current versions of OpenStack and possibly incompatible with Ussuri ?  Thoughts ? )
There may be a cleanup activity later to remove our building of panko images, etc.. from stx/upstream  or remove the OCF script from stx/ha  also

Well, we are not incompatible with Ussuri in any aspect right now since OSH claims support to it. That said, folks at OSH dropped support to Panko because Openstack decided to retire it completely due to lack of maintenance and I don't think there is a replacement for this service atm.

I think that from the stx-openstack standpoint, we should support whatever OSH supports, am I right to assume that?

WRO is a different topic, I'd take that offline with you.
